Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2009 02:39AM glostagirl wrote: I'm so sorry to hear of your wife's diagnosis.  Sadly, despite what many in the medical community want us to believe, there is no age minimum with breast cancer.  You may not be aware that this year a 10 year old girl from California was diagnosed with breast cancer. Her family started a thread on this web site looking for info, I believe it's still active.  This made national headlines.  In the 2 years I've been dealing with bc I've heard of many young women who have been diagnosed.  You should do an internet search for sites dedicated to young survivors of bc. Again, sorry for your wife to having to join us, but glad you found this site, it has a wealth of information you should be sure to take advantage of during the journey. I think many people in your shoes would consider a medical malpractice suit against the dr. who told her she was to young and not to worry.  It might be wise to document her experience, get copies of her medical records from this dr.'s office and seek legal advice from an experienced malpractice attorney.   Good luck to you both

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2009 02:32PM glostagirl wrote: Dear cjsocal and Nana,  You may be starting to realize this on your own.  Your daughter and grand daughter's diagnosis is going to have far reaching effects.  I get chills just thinking about what this means to the pediatric and breast cancer communities.   So many of us have already posted with prayers, well wishes and positive energy, you have our world on your side.  I don't usually post messages like this, but I just can't stop thinking about your Hannah.  I know it will be a comfort to her when she learns of all this support.   Good luck with oncology.  We will be here should you have questions or concerns in the future.  All the best to Hannah, her famiy and friends
Posts.Title: HELP! 10 year old with bc cjsocal Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2009 01:21PM - edited Apr 15, 2009 03:51PM by glostagirl This totally blows me away.  A very startling eye opener. My son just turned 11 and I know how I'd feel if in your shoes.  I would do anything for him. That's him in my avatar, to the right (a few years ago).  (I don't know why this text went gray & small, I can't get it to change back, that's why the Edit) I did recently hear through a friend of a young girl who went through something similar, finding a lump, etc....  It was not taken seriously, and no tests or follow up were done. She died at the age of 16. You're daughter is so lucky to have you as parents and lucky to have docs who listened!  You should get copies of all her medical records, path reports, surgical notes, etc....  You can get CD's of any imaging as well.  When I needed mine I called a week in advance for the CD's with accompanying paper reports and then went in person to each department for doctor's reports. As tkone said, fight the fight!  There is much info to be garnered from this site and sites geared to specific types of cancer.   I'm confident that you will figure out what to do next, do the research, and you'll know what's best for your daughter.  I have learned the hard way, through my own journey, that we must be our own advocates, cannot stress that enough! Let me also say that there are many resources for treatment.  The most talented and caring doctors will help you with your insurance company, just don't be afraid to ask. There are amazing plastic surgery resources as well, should your daughter be in need.  Lots of info right on this site.  Use the Discussion Board search tool.  She may not need much until she develops.  Don't give up until you find the best, they may not be in your back yard, but they are out there and they are passionate about reconstruction.   If you don't mind, I see my plastic surgeon tomorrow and would like to discuss this with her.  She is one of the extremely talented, caring, passionate ones.  I'll pass along any insights she has.  Good luck, you all will be in my thoughts
Posts.Title: HELP! 10 year old with bc cjsocal Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2009 05:21AM - edited Apr 18, 2009 03:56PM by glostagirl The most recognizable pink ribbon is associated with the Breast Cancer Research Foundation, founded in the US in 1993 by Evelyn H. Lauder.   In 2005, BCRF launched the current version and hot pink color of the ribbon.  Here is a contact page. www.bcrfcure.org/about_contact...  General Office: 646-497-2600 Fax: 646-497-0890 Email: bcrf@bcrfcure.org Toll-free: 1-866-FIND-A-CURE (346-3228) Mailing address:  The Breast Cancer Research Foundation  60 East 56th Street  8th floor  New York, N.Y. 10022  After this posting, I'm off to visit Hannah's web site.  I am among the many who have been, and will be, touched by this story.  It puts many things in a very different perspective.  Thank you for sharing her story.  I know it will make a difference in this world.  It already has for me.

Posts.Title: What we wish we had known about chemo before we started! ddlatt kerry_lamb

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2012 01:21PM glostagirl wrote: I had a lumpectomy for a 2.5 cm lump.  The scar was small, perhaps 1-1/2 inch, there was a bit of a divot from tissue removal, but in a bra was not noticable.  I had more pain from the sentinal lymphnode biopsy than from the lumpectomy.  There was an additional incision for that in my armpit, it was very sore and tight, but certainly not debilitating. I think I only took pain meds for a day or two.   I do know that anesthesia makes me nauseous so I asked for meds for that and did not have any problems.  Anti-nauseau meds can cause constipation.  Take a stool softener before the surgery if that is a concern.   This is a day surgery, you'll spend a few hours in recovery and then go home the day of the procedure.  You'll need someone to drive you.  I went downhill skiing a few weeks later which helped alot with range of movement issues I had with the lymphnode removal.    I don't think anyone could accurately tell you what your breast will look like after since it depends on your surgeon, the original size of your breast, where your lump is and how much tissue is removed to get clear margins.  You might consider a pre-surgery consult with a plastic surgeon. Ask your breast surgeon for a referral. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy - what can i expect? Shayne Angelaw69

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2009 10:37PM glostagirl wrote: I have a recurrence just (barely) 5 months out of tx!  I've delayed posting this info as I've been in shock and truly did not want to scare anyone with this bad news.  However, it seems to me that we, especially TN's need to get info out to others, so that's why I'm sharing my experience. DX 1/04/08 (see below for specifics)  Lumpectomy 02/08, A/C x4  ending 05/30/08, Rads x 33 incld. boost 07-08/08.  I had a good surgery with, what my surgeon described as, very clean margins.  Typical but not excessive issues with chemo and no problems with rads.  (see my original info at top of thread).  I got the results of my biopsy and it's back.  IDC, .8 cm, poorly differentiated cells.  Give or take a day or two, it's a year since my original diagnosis.  I'm totally in shock and don't like what I know comes next.   As difficult as it all is, it's been good to know that I'm not alone, you're all out there fighting along side.  From all I've read in your various posts, I've got some good info and questions for my surgeon and oncs.  They won't know what hit 'um!!! The moral of the story, don't take anything for granted, keep up the vigil on your own body!  Glostagirl

Posts.Title: New lump 4 months after completing treatments, any others? glostagirl apple

Posts.Content: Dec 25, 2008 03:59AM glostagirl wrote: Hillary, you've gotten excellent info.  I had the  same sugery last February, followed by 4 A/C infusions and radiation.  I'm triple neg, so I don't need Tamoxifen.    In the winter I live in northern Utah, ski country, and was able to ski 4 weeks after surgery.  I found that the upper body motions used in skiing were extremely helpful in loosening the tightness I felt in my chest and arm.   So when you feel up to it, get moving!!!  Yoga stretching is helpfull as well. I finished up rads in August, am still sore and swollen.  I can tell you that it does take a long time to heal and that everybody is different.  My scar has faded considerably from what it was and the indentation from the lumpectomy is slowly filling in.  The swelling and soreness is slowly subsiding, saw my med. onc yesterday, she thinks all looks great.
Posts.Title: Just had lumpectomy and still confused ccdh MBrads

Posts.Content: May 22, 2012 06:38PM glostagirl wrote: Yes, this happened to me as well.  It was 6 weeks after surgery, all drains were out and I was healing well.  I'd had one infusion of chemo and a Neulasta shot, about a week later I noticed swelling, redness, pain and ran a fever.  It happened pretty fast.  My MO had me come right in to the infusion unit, put me on IV antibiotics.  They also did do a blood culture.   They were going to admit me, but it was quite late at night by the time they were finished up and I would have to go to the hospital emergency room to get admitted, I just couldn't tolerate that at the time and insisted that I wanted to go home, as I was feeling much better.  If my temp hadn't come down they weren't going to let me go, but it did.   Fortunately for me the infection cleared up pretty quick but didn't heal until after I was done with chemo.  I did have to delay my 2nd infusion by a week for things to clear up.  I took oral antibiotics as well.   You didn't mention if you were on chemo, but it does lower your immunity to fight infection.  I'm not a doctor but I wouldn't think you have blood poisoning.    Hope this helps and that you heal quickly.
Posts.Title: In the hospital and need your help dearjilly glostagirl

Posts.Content: glostagirl wrote: I just joined this site in the hope of finding others who may share my experience.  I was a good girl and did everything my docs recommended.  Surgery (02/08), chemo 03-05/08, radiation 07-08/08).... In the months since I finished radiation in August, I've had a post check up with my rad. onc. and a physical with my P.C.P. (late October) both did thorough breast exams and all looked good.  In December, I myself found that the swelling and numbness had reduced enough to start doing my own thorough exams, to my shock, I immediately found a lump.  I already had  a one year from original diagnosis (01/08) mammo,  a 6 mo. med. onc. check up and gyn pap scheduled for the end of the month so I decided to stick with that schedule.   My GYN confirmed that there was a mass.  The new lump is about an 1-1/2 in. away from the original mass, is small @ .8cm and quite sore.  The pain ranges from a dull ache to a burning, stinging sensation. After the mammo, they immediately did an ultra sound, confirmed a mass and recommended a biopsy as soon as possible.  This has been scheduled for Monday, 12/29.  I am so hoping that this is residual tissue damage/repair from radiation but feel the need to ask if anyone's had a similar experience so soon after tx???  Thanks in advance for your replies.  Edited for clarification ...."We must see all scars as beauty. ....Because take it from me, a scar does not form on the dying. A scar means, I survived." Chris Cleave, Little Bee Dx 1/5/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/2 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Surgery 2/22/2008 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel Surgery 3/27/2009 Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Right; Reconstruction (right): IGAP flap Surgery 6/20/2012 Reconstruction (right): DIEP flap Surgery 11/14/2012 Reconstruction (right) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 4, 2009 04:46PM - edited May 4, 2009 04:52PM by glostagirl Pseudoangiomatous Stromal Hyperplasia of the Breast Pseudoangiomatous stromal hyperplasia (PASH) is a benign myofibroblastic proliferation of nonspecialized mammary stroma. Its clinicopathologic spectrum ranges from incidental, microscopic foci to clinically and mammographically evident breast masses [98]. Originally, hormonal stimulation (particularly with progesterone) was suggested in the etiology of PASH, on the basis of observations that this disease is most frequently seen in premenopausal women or in elderly women taking hormone-replacement therapy, and because similar histologic findings are seen in normal mammary stroma during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle. However, thelesion has since been found in men and in women not taking hormone therapy, and only a small percentage of PASH cases are positive for estrogen receptors or for progesterone receptors [98, 99]. Clinically, rare cases of PASH present as a well-circumscribed, dense, rubbery mass mimicking a fibroadenoma or a phyllodes tumor. Both the mammographic and sonographic features in PASH are nonspecific, so biopsy of these lesions is necessary to exclude a malignancy [99, 100]. On gross examination, PASH is usually a well-demarcated mass with a smooth external surface. The cut surface consists of homogeneous white and rubbery tissue. Histologically, a complex network of anastomosing slit-like spaces within a densely collagenous stroma characterizes PASH. The histologic appearance may cause confusion with mammary angiosarcoma, so immunohistochemical vascular markers are used for distinction. Immunohistochemically, the bland spindle cells that line these spaces are strongly positive for vimentin and CD34 and negative for cytokeratin and factor VIII. The recommended treatment for PASH is wide local excision. Although PASH can recur, patient prognosis is good [98]. I hope you find this helpful.   It seems that rare cases of this can be malignant, hopefully the lumpectomy will take care of the problem for you. I've never heard of PASH which is what made me look it up on-line.  Also, if you do a search of this discussion board, you will find quite a few postings on PASH.  Good luck

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2012 06:09PM glostagirl wrote: Hi Frapp, I don't know if this will help you or not, but here goes.  I too am well endowed at 34DD.  I had a uni-lateral in 2009 and went 3 years without recon.  It had a very profound effect on my psyche.  I hated it and as time passed that sentiment grew stronger.  I had a difficult time finding a prosthetic that was symmetrical with my natural side, plus the prosthetic was very uncomfortable; hot in the summer and cold in the winter.  I never felt, as they say, "comfortable in my own skin".  When you're surgeon states that a prosthetic will take care of the lop-sided issue, she is not speaking from personal experience and her statement only address your outward appearance, not the day to day issues of living that way.  You might mention this to her because too often the psychological effects of this are brushed aside. Although I'm in my 50's, I'm in good shape, very active and felt I didn't want to go the rest of my life lop-sided.  I considered, briefly, a prophylactic mx on the natural side, but couldn't go thru with it.  I've ended up going for DIEP reconstruction on the cancer side and a reduction on the other.  I'm halfway through the process and glad I went this route. I'm not saying what's right for me is right for you, we're all different, our life circumstances are different, only you can decide what's best for you.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: To be flat or uniboob, please help Frapp Lily55

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2012 01:06PM glostagirl wrote: Could you take an oral anti-coagulant.  I couldn't afford Lovenox with my insurance, so my doc ok'd Xarelto, still pricey but half the cost of Lovenox.  Unlike Coumadin, Xarelto get's in your blood stream right away.

Posts.Content: May 2, 2012 09:42AM glostagirl wrote: So happy to hear this news, thanks for updating us all.   I was not familiar with this condition.  I think many of us tend to research our own particular diagnosis and not so much others.   So I had to look up what your dx was and came across this very interesting radiology site I thought might be of interest to you.  The last few images are of particular importance to what you're going through and may help you decide if you want to go for biopsy.  It's great the radiologist was willing to be there and answer questions, they don't often do that.  Probably because of your age and gender.  You should be sure to get a copy of your medical records from this process and a CD of the images, never know when you may need them in the future.       http://www.radiologyassistant.nl/en/49a3cce262026 This is definately cause to celebrate with pizza and beer!
